segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It is a very hectic day.

segments.text: I have the model and I've been playing with it a little bit.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I'm not an expert at this, so yeah.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: There's all these ways we can talk about it's better at this metric or it can do this amazing coding demo that GPT-4 couldn't.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But the thing that has been most striking for me is in ways that are both big and small, going back from GPT-5 to our previous generation model is just so painful.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's just worse at everything.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I've taken for granted that there is a fluency and a depth of intelligence with GPT-5 that we haven't had in any previous model.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's an integrated model, so you don't have to pick on our model switcher and know if you should use GPT-40 or 03 or 04 mini or any of the complicated things.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's just one thing that works.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And it is like having PhD level experts in every field available to you 24-7 for whatever you need.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Not only to ask anything, but also to do anything for you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So if you need a piece of software created, it can kind of do it from scratch all at once.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If you need a research report on some complicated topic, it can do that for you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If you needed to plan an event for you, it could do that too.

segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Because I was trying that out.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It's much better at things like that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The robustness and reliability has greatly increased and that's very helpful for agentic workflows.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I'm like very impressed by how long and complex of a task it can carry out.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So we did a call a couple of weeks ago when I was bugging you about what sectors and themes to invest in for the next decade.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I don't want to talk about that too much.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I thought we'll keep today about first principles and how the world is changing by virtue of all that is changing in the world that you dominate.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So the very first thing I want to start with is if I were a 25 year old boy or girl living in Mumbai or Bangalore or in India, I know you've said a bunch of times that colleges are not holding on to the place of relevance they might have had when I was growing up.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But what do I do now?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: A, what do I study?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: If I'm starting a company, what kind of company do I start?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Or if I were to even find a job, what industry do you think has some kind of tailwind?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I'm not talking 10 years down the line, but even as close as three to five years down the line.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: First of all, I think this is probably the most exciting time to be starting out one's career.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Maybe ever.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think that 25-year-old in Mumbai can probably do more than any previous 25-year-old in history could.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's really amazing what you can do with a tool like this.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I felt the same way when I was 25 and the tools then were not as amazing as tools we have now, but we had the computer revolution and we could do things, a 25 year old then could do things that no 25 year old in history before would have been able to.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And now that's happening in a huge way.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So whether you want to start a company or be a programmer or go work in kind of any other industry,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: create new media, whatever it is, the ability for one person to use these tools and have great ideas and implement them with what would have taken decades of experience or teams of people is really quite remarkable.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: In terms of particular industries, I am very excited about what AI is going to mean for science and the amount of science that one person will be able to discover and the rate at which they can do that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Clearly, it's transforming
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: what it means to program computers in a huge way.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And people will be able to create completely new kinds of software in a huge new scale.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Definitely for startups, if you have an idea for a new business, the ability for a very tiny team to do a huge amount of work is great.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But it feels like this is just now a very open canvas.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: People are limited.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: to a degree that they've never been before, only by the quality and creativity of their ideas, and you have these incredible tools to help you realize them.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Is there anything in particular you want to say about GPT-5, then I can ask you questions around that?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: GPT-5 does feel to us like it's going to be another big step forward in how people use these systems.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The level of capability, the level of robustness, the reliability,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: a lot of tasks in life to create software, to answer questions, to learn, to work more efficiently.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: This is a pretty significant step forward.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Each time we've had one of these, we have been amazed by the human potential it unlocks.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And in particular, India is now our second largest market in the world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It may become our largest.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: taken a lot of feedback from users in India about what they'd like from us, better support for languages, more affordable access, much more.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And we've been able to put that into this model and upgrades to chat GPT.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So we're committed to continuing to work on that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But the, you know, every time we've had a major leap forward in how the capability we can bring to users, we've been amazed by what those, those 25 year olds go off and do in terms of creating new companies
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: learning better, getting better medical advisor, whatever else.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Is there anything that I could build on top of GPT-5 today as a 25 year old in India that you think are low hanging fruits per se that I should definitely look at?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I think you could build an entire startup way more efficiently than you ever could before.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Now, this is obviously I'm biased because this is like near and dear to my heart.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But the fact that as a 25 year old in India or anywhere else,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: maybe with a couple of friends, maybe just by yourself, you could use GPT-5 to help you write the software for a product much more efficiently, help you handle customer support, help you write marketing and communications plans, help you review legal documents, all of these things that would have taken a lot of people and a lot of expertise, and you now have GPT-5 to help you do all of this, that's pretty amazing.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If I could push you to be like a bit more specific and say, I get science, but what do I study?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Say I've been studying engineering or commerce or arts or something like that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Is there any specific thing I study in order to use AI to develop something in science?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I think the most important specific thing to study is just getting really good at using the new AI tools.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think learning is valuable for its own sake and learning to learn is this like meta skill that will serve you throughout life.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And whether you're learning, you know, engineering, like computer engineering or biology or any other field like that, if you get good at learning things, you can learn new things quickly.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But fluency with the tools is, you know, is really important.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: When I was in college or in high school, it seemed to me that the obvious thing to do was learn a program.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I didn't know exactly what I was going to use that for, but there was this new frontier that seemed very high leverage and important to get good at.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And right now, learning how to use AI tools is probably the most important specific hard skill to learn.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And the difference between people who are really good at it, really AI native and think of everything in terms of those tools and don't is huge.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: There's other general skills.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Learning kind of like to be adaptable and resilient, which I think is something really learnable.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That's like quite valuable in a world that's changing so fast.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Learning how to figure out what people want is really quite important.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Before this, I used to be a startup investor and people would ask me what the most important thing for startup founders to figure out was.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And my predecessor, Paul Graham, had this answer that has always stuck with me for people to give to founders.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And it became the motto for Y Combinator, which is make something people want.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And that sounds like such an easy instruction.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I have watched so many people try so hard to learn how to figure that out and fail.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And then I've watched many people work really hard to learn how to do that and get great at it over a career.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So that's something as well.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But in terms of the specifics, like are you supposed to take the biology class or the physics class?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I don't think it matters right now.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And if I were to build on top of that, and when you say learn to adapt and change and learn AI tools,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: faster.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Is there a path?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I'm just looking for a light that somebody could begin walking towards.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: How does one get better at the AI tools that are available out there?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, one great thing to do.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: GPT-5 is quite good at helping to create small pieces of software very quickly.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And much better than any model that I've used.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: few weeks, I have surprised myself how much I've used it to create a piece of software to solve some little problem that I have in my life.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And, you know, it's been an interesting creative process, because I'll ask it for a first draft, I'll start using that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And then I'll say, hey, with this feature, it would be better.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Or with this other thing, I'd be able to do something differently.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Or, you know, I have started using it and realized that with my workflow, I really needed this.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And by putting more and more of the things that I have to do in this kind of a workflow,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That's been a very interesting way for me to learn how to use this.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You mentioned Paul Graham and I was reading this letter or report he wrote in 2009 where he spoke about five founders to watch out for.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I think you were 19 at the time and he mentioned you along with people like Steve Jobs and Larry and Sergey.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Why was that?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You hadn't accomplished anything of note like they had.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What did Paul see in you?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And what do you think is the innate skill set that sets you apart from your peers?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: That was very nice of him.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I remember that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I certainly, I remember at the time feeling that it was very deeply undeserved, but grateful that he said that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, there's like a lot of people who are starting great companies.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: lucky here in many ways, we've also worked super hard.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Maybe the one thing that I would, that I think we have done here well is to take a very long time horizon and think very independently.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, when we started, it was like four and a half years before we had a first product and it was very uncertain.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We were just doing research, trying to figure out how to get AI to work.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And we had very different ideas then
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: the rest of the world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But I think that ability to sort of trust our own conviction over a long time horizon without a lot of external feedback was very helpful.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Is that a V or an I thing?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Because I'm speaking about when you were 19.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Oh, sorry.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I thought you were asking about open AI.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Me when I was 19, I barely remember that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I don't know.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I was like a naive 19-year-old that didn't really know what he was doing.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: This is not false modesty.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think I've done impressive things now.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But my own self-conception in 19 was like deeply unsure of myself and very unimpressive.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If the world were to be, the world of tomorrow were to be an AI kingdom of sorts, you're definitely some kind of prince.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I don't know if you follow Machiavelli, but he used to say a very interesting thing.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: He said that a prince should always appear but not be religious, compassionate, trustworthy, humane and honest.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Do you think this particular projection of...
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I've watched a lot of your interviews of late and I've heard you say repeatedly that you're not formidable and use words like that.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: this projection of humility, is it apt for the world we live in or the world you're walking into?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I'm not sure it's apt for either one, but when I was 19, to go back to what you said, I assumed that the people running these big tech companies really had it all figured out.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: and there were adults in the room and somebody had a plan and there were these people that were like way different than me that understood how to do things and had this like, the companies were like running very well and there was like not much drama and everything was like, just everything was being handled by the adults.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And now that I'm supposed to be the adult in the room, I will tell you, I think no one has a plan.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: No one really has it all working smoothly.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Everyone or at least I am figuring out as they go
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And you have things you want to build and then things go wrong and you bet on the wrong people or the right people and you get a technological breakthrough here or you don't there and you just keep putting one foot in front of another and you put your head down and work and you have these tactics that some of them become great strategies, some of them don't.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You try something and the market reacts in some way or your competitors react in some way and you do something else.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And now my conception is everybody is kind of figuring it out as they go.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Everybody is like learning on the job.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I don't think that's like false humility.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think that's just the way the world works.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And it's like a little, it's a little strange to be on this side of it, but that is what it seems like.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I'm not even speaking so much about the authenticity of the humility or not, but
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: More again from the lens of somebody starting to build for tomorrow, because that's who we speak to.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Is that a good image to project into the world?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Does it... the image of humility really work today?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You mean, should someone project that image?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, I certainly have a very negative reaction to... people who are...
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: projecting certainty and confidence when they don't really know what's going to happen.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And the reason is not just because it's annoying, which it is, but also because I think if you have that kind of a mindset, it is harder to have the culture of intellectual openness and to sort of like listen to other viewpoints and make good decisions.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: A thing I say all the time to people is no one knows what happens next.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And the more you forget that and the more you're like, I am smarter than everybody else.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I have a master plan.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I'm not going to pay attention to like what my users are saying or where the technology takes us or how the world is reacting.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But, you know, I know better and the world doesn't know as much.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think you just make worse decisions.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So having that kind of open mindset and the sort of like curiosity and willingness to adapt to new data and change your mind, I think that's super important.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Like the number of times we have thought we knew something to get smacked in the face by reality here has been a lot.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And one of our strengths as a company is when that happens, we change what we're going to do where that that's been, I think that's been really great and a big part of what's helped us succeed.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So, so maybe there are other ways to succeed and maybe, you know, projecting a ton of bravado into the world works,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: the best founders that I have watched up close throughout my career have all been more like the sort of quick learning and adapting style.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And you probably know more about this than most because of your role at Y Combinator.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I have a lot of data points on it at least, yeah.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: When we met in Washington a couple of years ago at the White House, I remember when we were speaking and you went somewhere, I was speaking to your partner.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And you guys had a kid.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We did.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And how is that?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Uh, it is my favorite thing ever.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But I mean, I, I know that like, I have nothing that is not a cliche to say here.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Um, but it is the coolest, most amazing, most like emotionally overwhelming in the best ways and hard ways to experience every
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Everything everyone said about how great it is, how intense it is, how it's like a kind of love you didn't know you could feel, it's all true.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I have nothing to add other than I strongly recommend it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I think it's been really wonderful.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's amazing.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I ponder on this a lot, Sam, kids, why people have kids, and also questions like what happens to religion and marriage tomorrow?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Can I ask you why you had a kid?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Like family has always been an incredibly important thing to me.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And going, like it just, it felt like, it felt like the most, and I didn't even know how much I underestimated what it was actually going to be like, but it felt like the most important and meaningful and fulfilling thing I could imagine doing.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And it has so far, so early exceeded all expectations.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Do you think it's the biological need
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: to procreate?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I don't know, there's like, this seems like a thing that is so deep, it's difficult to put into words, but I feel confident, like everyone I know looking back on their life who has had a great career and had a family has either said, you know, I'm so glad I took the time to have kids.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That was one of the most important things I've ever done.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: the best things I've ever done.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Or they've said that was by far the best thing I've ever done.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That was way more important than any of the work I ever did.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I was like willing to take the leap of faith that that would be true for me too.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And it certainly seems like it will be.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's like, yeah, it is.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And if it is just a biological hack, I don't care, I'm so happy.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But it, you know, it like, there's a sense of responsibility and kind of like family is the word that keeps coming to mind that is just really great.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The world seems to be having lesser kids, and do you have an insight into the future of marriage, religion, and kids?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yeah, I hope that creating family, creating community, whatever you want to call it, will become far more important in a sort of post-AGI world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think it's a real problem for society that those things have been in retreat.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think that
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: that just feels strictly bad to me.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I'm obviously not sure why that's been happening, but I hope we'll really reverse course on that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And in a world where people have more abundance, more time, more sort of resources and potential and ability, I think it's like pretty clear that family and community are two of the things that make us the happiest.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I hope we will turn back to that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: As societies get more affluent, if one were to buy into the mimetic desires of people, we all tend to want what other people want, not necessarily what other people have.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: If we all had more, do you think we would still want more if we all had enough?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I do sort of think that human demand, desire,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: ability to play status games, whatever is like, it seems pretty limitless.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I don't think that's necessarily bad, or not all bad.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But yeah, I think we will figure out new things to want and new things to compete over.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Do you think the world retains, largely the world retains the current model of capitalism and democracy in a way?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Let me give you a scenario.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I would bet not.

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Like let's figure out something to do here.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: which was this really important scientific discovery that for a while looked like it was going to capture a ton of the value and then turned out to be something that just gets built into like tons of products and services.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And you don't really think about, you know, the fact that you're using transistors all day long, it's just kind of in everything and all these companies make incredible products and profits from it in this very distributed way.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I would guess that's what happens.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And it's not like one company has ever
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: half of global GDP.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: At one point, I did worry that that might happen, but I think that was a naive take.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Right.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But do you think the odds of the world moving towards socialism go up or if something gets that large, will it get nationalized and we become more socialist?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I don't know if something will get nationalized.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I don't know if the world will like officially turn towards socialism, but I expect that
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I expect that like social support or redistribution or whatever you want to call it will increase over time as society gets richer and as sort of the technological landscape shifts.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I don't know what way it's going to happen and I expect in different countries, it'll happen in different ways.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Like I think you'll see experimentation of like new kinds of sovereign wealth funds, new kinds of like universal basic income ideas, redistribution of AI compute.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I don't know exactly what, but I suspect we'll see a lot of experimentation in society here.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: On universal basic income, I think world coin was a very interesting experiment.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Can you tell us a bit about what's happening there?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Uh, the idea was, could we, you know, we have all this AI coming.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We really want to like care about humans is special.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Can we find a way to a privacy preserving way to identify unique humans and then create a new network and a new currency around that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Uh, so it's a very interesting experiment, still early, but growing quite fast.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: AGI eliminates scarcity or scarcity by virtue of increasing productivity.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Could one also assume that it would be deflationary in nature?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Capital or money loses its ability to return a rate of return and capital no longer remains a moat in the world of tomorrow?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I feel confused about this.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think if you look at the basic economic principles, it's supposed to be hugely deflationary.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And yet, if the world decides that building out AI compute today is super important to things tomorrow, maybe something very strange happens with the economy and maybe capital is really, really important because every piece of compute is so valuable.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I was asking someone at dinner the other night if they thought that interest rates should be minus 2% or 25%.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And he kind of laughed.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: He's like, well, that's a ridiculous question.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It has to be.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And then he stopped and said, actually, I'm not sure.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I think it's like, yeah, it should be deflationary eventually, but I could see it being weird in the short term.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's actually a very interesting thing to say.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Do you suspect it would be minus 2%?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Eventually.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But I'm not sure.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And maybe it's just like we're in this massive expansionary time where you're trying to like build the Dyson Sphere and the solar system and you're borrowing money at crazy rates to do that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And then there's more expansion beyond and more and more and I don't know.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I find it very hard to see more than a few years in the future at this point.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The conversation we were having a couple of weeks ago,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I was doing more research on the sectors you had suggested.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I think we agreed on older and sicker world.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You also made a case for as discretionary spend goes up, gateway luxury brands might do well.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yeah.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What happens to them in a deflationary world?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Because the value of these purchases go down.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Maybe not.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I mean, in a deflationary world,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: face huge deflationary pressure and others can be the sink for all of the extra capital.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I'm actually not sure they do go down in a deflationary world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I would bet they go up actually.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Because the excess capital has to flow somewhere.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: When you look at classical economic theory like Adam Smith and stuff like that, the Austrian school always spoke about the marginal utility of things.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: If you have one kettle at home to make tea, it has X in value.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: When you have two kettles, it still has some value.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But when you have 20 kettles, it has no value.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Do you think the world goes in that direction?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yeah, so 20 kettles doesn't help you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But even if you're only going to spend two hours a day playing video games or whatever, and that amount of time is fixed,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so you don't need 20 hours worth of video games.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If that two hours of games gets better and more entertaining forever and ever and ever, and just keeps getting more and more compelling, that still has value to you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I think there are a lot of categories where we will find that people can just get much better stuff, even if they don't necessarily get more of them.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think we'll see this in a really big way.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Do you think there's a use case for the rappers that are getting built on these large models right now?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Like I was in the U.S. recently and I met Harvey for example.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What happens to a rapper like that?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Does it get innovated out by the model itself at some point of time?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Some of them yes and some of them no.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Sometimes you can obviously predict when one is going to go one way or the other.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And sometimes it really depends on the choices the company makes down the line.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The main thing I would say is using AI itself does not create a defensible business.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You see this with every technology boom where people are like, well, I must start up doing X and because I'm using the latest technology trend, the normal rules of business don't apply to me.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And that's never true.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You've always got to parlay that advantage that comes from using the new technology into a durable business with real value that gets created.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And it's kind of a race against the clock to do that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So, you know, you can definitely build an amazing thing with AI, but then you have to go build a real defensible layer around it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The example of Amazon, for example, if I sold a certain kind of t-shirt and I sold a lot and Amazon had all the data, eventually Amazon probably started a white labeled brand, which was very similar to mine and cannibalize my business almost.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Should one worry that will happen here as well, because you're no longer just a model, but you're foray into so many different businesses?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I'd come back to that example of the transistor.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We are building this general purpose technology that you can integrate into something in a lot of ways, but we keep following our equivalent of Moore's law and the general capability keeps going up.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If you build a business that gets better, the business gets better when that model gets better.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: then you should keep doing well if we continue to make progress.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If you build a business where when the model gets better, your business gets worse because the wrapper was too thin or whatever, then that's probably bad in the same way that it's been bad in other technology revolutions.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So there are clearly companies building on top of AI models that are creating huge value
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: and very deep relationships with their customers for themselves.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Cursor is like a recent example of a company that is just exploding in popularity and I think really durable relationships with their customers.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And then there's many others that don't and that's kind of, that's always the case.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It does seem to me like there are more companies getting created now
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: than in previous technological revolutions that feel like they have a chance at real durability.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Maybe an example we could use to ground this is when the iPhone first came out and the app store first came out, the first set of apps were pretty light and a lot of them ended up being features that kind of made it into future versions of iOS.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You could like sell a flashlight for a dollar that turned on the flash on your phone
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: made a lot of dollars doing that, but it wasn't sticky because eventually Apple just added that into the operating system where it belonged.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But if you started something that was like complicated and the iPhone was just an enabler for it like Uber, that was a very valuable long-term thing to do.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And in the early days, like the GPT-3 days, I think you had a lot of kind of toy applications as you should, many of which didn't need to be standalone companies or products.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But now as the market's matured, you're really seeing some of these more durable businesses form.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If you lay emphasis on owning the customer almost, like the interface with the customer, would you say the relationship gets deeper when I sell a service on top of your model versus a product?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Because if it's a product company, the exchange happens once.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But if it's a service company, it happens repeatedly.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And there is room for me to build and taste in that transaction, which is repetitive in nature.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: A small part of my world or a part of my world is creating content which I do once a month.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: If a model to a large extent is able to factor in my vintage, my tenure and my evolution and throw out an output which is predictive in nature with a fair degree of efficiency,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Now, if I behave in the same predictable manner tomorrow will be less valuable than me being contrarian, contrarian not to the world, but contrarian to my own behavior almost.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So do you think the world inordinately favors contrarian behavior tomorrow?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yeah, that's a good point.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think so.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think the thing I'm thinking is how much will the models learn to do that?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, you want to be contrarian and right.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Most of the time you're contrarian, you're contrarian and wrong, and that's not that helpful.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But yeah, I bet the ability to come up with the kind of contrarian and right idea that the models today just can't do at all, and maybe they'll get better at some point, that value of that should go up over time.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Getting good at doing things models can't do seems like an obvious increase in value.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Outside of being contrarian, is there anything else that I could do that a model will take longer to learn?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Look, the models are going to be much smarter than we are, but there's a lot of things that people care about that have nothing to do with intelligence.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Maybe there can be like an AI podcast host that is much better than you at asking interesting questions and, you know, kind of engaging, whatever.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I personally don't think that podcast host
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: that AI podcast host is likely to be more popular than you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: People really care about other humans.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: This is like very deep.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: People want to know a little bit about your life story, what got you here.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: They want to be able to like talk to other people about this like shared sense of who you are.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And there's like some cultural and social value in that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We are obsessed with other people.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Why is that Sam?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Why do you think that is?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I think that's also like deep in our biology.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, again, they're common.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You don't fight things that are deep in biology.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, I think it'd make ton of sense of why we would evolve that way.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But, you know, here we are.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So, you know, we're going to keep caring about real people.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And even if the AI podcast host is much smarter than you, I think it's very unlikely he'll be more popular than you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So in a perverse way, being stupider will be more novel than being smart.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I don't know if it's like a stupider
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: or smarter that has the novelty, but I think being a real person in a world of unlimited AI content will increase in value.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Is a real person somebody who screws up, unlike a model?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I mean, certainly real people do screw up, so maybe that's part of what we associate with a real person, I'm not sure.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But I do think we just, knowing that it's a real person or not, we really extremely care about.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What is the difference between AGI and human intelligence, today and tomorrow?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So with GPT-5 you have something that is incredibly smart in a lot of domains at tasks that take seconds to a few minutes.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's very superhuman at knowledge, at pattern recognition, at recall on these shorter term tasks.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But in terms of figuring out what questions to ask or to work on something over a very long period of time, we are definitely not
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: close to human performance.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And an interesting example that one of our researchers gave me recently is if you look at our performance in math, a couple of years ago we could solve math problems that would take like an expert human a few minutes to solve.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Recently we got gold level performance on the International Math Olympiad.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Each of those problems takes about an hour and a half.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So we've gone from a problem, a thinking horizon of a few minutes to an hour and a half.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: To prove an important new mathematical theorem maybe takes like a thousand hours.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And you can predict when we can do a thousand hour problem, but certainly in the world today we cannot at all.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so that's like another dimension where AI can't do it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I was in the U.S. between SF, between San Francisco and New York the last couple of months, and I met a whole bunch of AI founders.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: The one thing everybody seemed to agree on is like for AI, the US is a few years ahead of most others.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They also thought that for robotics, China seems to be ahead.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Do you have a view on robotics and what happens there, like humanoid or other form of robotics?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I think it will be incredibly important in a couple of years.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think one of the things that is going to feel most
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: AGI-like is seeing robots just walk by you on the street doing kind of normal day-to-day tasks.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Is there a reason why they need to have human-like form?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, you can certainly have non-humanoid forms, but the world is really built for humans.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, like door handles, steering wheels in cars, factories, like a lot of this is built for... We built it for our own kind of morphology.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So there will of course be other specialized robots too, but the world like is built and I hope stays built for us.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So, you know, robots that match that form factor, it seems like a good idea.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If I'm a young guy looking to start a robotics company, but somebody else has manufacturing scale and I really want as an Indian guy to be able to build and compete there, how do I make up for manufacturing scale as someone starting up?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, eventually, once you build enough robots, they can make more copies of themselves.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But in the short term, I think you probably have to find some really good partners that know a lot about manufacturing.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And we're interested in robots, so we're thinking about this.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And it's definitely a new skill for us to learn.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Sam, what happens to the form factor?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I've been using the cell phone for a long time.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I know you will not likely speak about what you're doing with Johnny Ive and what happens there.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But what happens to form factor overall?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: One of the things that I think we'll be defining about the difference of AI versus the sort of previous way we've been using computers and technology is you really want AI to be, have as much context as possible, do stuff for you and be proactive.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So a computer or a phone, you know, it's kind of either on or off.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But you might want AI to just be, you know, like a companion with you throughout your day and alerting you in different ways when it can do something to help you or when it's, you know, there's something really important you need to know or reminding you of something that you said you needed to do earlier in the day.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And the current form factors of computers are I think not quite right for that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: They do have this either on or off binary.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: that I think isn't quite what we want for the sort of sci-fi dream of the AI companion.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So the form factor that enables that, you could imagine a lot of things.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: There's people talking about glasses and wearables and things that sit on your table.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think the world will extreme with a lot of those, but this idea of sort of ambiently aware physical hardware, that feels like it's going to be important.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Is that the form factor with Johnny Ive, like a sensor?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So we'll try multiple products, but I think this idea of trying to build hardware that an AI companion can sort of embody itself in will be an important thread.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The last two things I want to ask you, Sam,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Fusion, because I know you've invested in helium and you're a big proponent of it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Would you put money on that?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It certainly helps a lot.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I suspect that we've already done sufficient damage to the climate.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We're going to have to undo some damage too, even if we got to switch to fusion right away.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But it would certainly be a great step forward.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If there is one large society in the world that seems most enthusiastic to transform with AI right now, it's India and the energy is incredible.

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And it's really like quite amazing to watch.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I feel like,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Guest
